document.title:
The heat kernel on
R n

para.p:
For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
(
R n
)
, we define
:
^ f
→
R n
C
by

Math.text: formulae@(hat@(f) * xi = F * f * xi = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(f * x * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(x)), xi element-of R ^ n)

para.p:
The statement of the Riemann-Lebesgue lemma is that
∈
^ f
⁢
C 0
(
R n
)
.

We denote by
S n
the Fréchet space of Schwartz functions
→
R n
C
.

If
α
is a multi-index, we define

Math.text: D ^ alpha = (D _ 1) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (D _ n) ^ (alpha _ n)
D _ alpha = i ^ (- absolute-value@(alpha)) * D ^ alpha = ((1 / i) * D _ 1) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * ((1 / i) * D _ n) ^ (alpha _ n)

para.p: and

Math.text: Delta = (D _ 1) ^ 2 + cdots + (D _ n) ^ 2

para.p:
Fix
n
, and for
> t 0
,
∈ x
R n
, define

Math.text: k _ t * x = k * open-interval@(t, x) = (4 * pi * t) ^ (- n / 2) * exponential@(- (absolute-value@(x)) ^ 2 / (4 * t))

para.p:
We call
k
the heat kernel. It is straightforward to check for any
> t 0
that
∈
k t
S n
. The heat kernel satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(k _ t * x = t ^ (- 1 / 2) ^ n * k _ 1 * t ^ (- 1 / 2) * x, formulae@(t > 0, x element-of R ^ n))

para.p:
For
> a 0
and
=
⁢ f
( x )
e
-
⁢ π a
| x |
2
, it is a fact that
=
⁢
^ f
( ξ )
⁢
a
-
/ n 2
e
-
/
⁢ π
| ξ |
2
a
. Using this, for any
> t 0
we get

Math.text: formulae@((hat@(k)) _ t * xi = e ^ (- 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2 * t), xi element-of R ^ n)

para.p:
Thus for any
> t 0
,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(k _ t * x * differential-d@(x)) = (hat@(k)) _ t * 0 = 1

para.p:
Then the heat kernel is an approximate identity: if
∈ f
⁢
L p
(
R n
)
,
1 ≤ p < ∞
, then
→
∥
-
* f
k t
f
∥
p
0
as
→ t 0
, and if
f
is a function on
R n
that is bounded and continuous, then for every
∈ x
R n
,
→
⁢
* f
k t
( x )
⁢ f
( x )
as
→ t 0
. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1
k 1
, and any
k t
, belong merely to
S n
and not to
⁢ D
(
R n
)
, which is demanded in the definition of an approximate identity in Rudin’s Functional Analysis, second ed. For each
> t 0
, because
∈
k t
S n
we have
∈
* f
k t
⁢
C ∞
(
R n
)
, and
=
⁢
D α
(
* f
k t
)
⁢
* f
D α
k t
for any multi-index
α
. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Gerald B. Folland, Introduction to Partial Differential Equations, second ed., p. 11, Theorem 0.14.

The heat operator is
-
D t
Δ
and the heat equation is
=
⁢
(
-
D t
Δ
)
u
0
. It is straightforward to check that

Math.text: formulae@((D _ t - Delta) * k * open-interval@(t, x) = 0, formulae@(t > 0, x element-of R ^ n))

para.p: that is, the heat kernel is a solution of the heat equation.

To get some practice proving things about solutions of the heat equation, we work out the following theorem from Folland. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Gerald B. Folland, Introduction to Partial Differential Equations, second ed., p. 144, Theorem 4.4. In Folland’s proof it is not apparent how the hypotheses on
u
and
D x
are used, and we make this explicit.

p.text:
Suppose that
: u
→
×
[ 0 , ∞ )
R n
C
is continuous, that
u
is
C 2
on
×
( 0 , ∞ )
R n
, that

Math.text: formulae@((D _ t - Delta) * u * open-interval@(t, x) = 0, formulae@(t > 0, x element-of R ^ n))

p.text:
and that
=
⁢ u
( 0 , x )
0
for
∈ x
R n
. If for every
> ϵ 0
there is some
C
such that

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(u * open-interval@(t, x)) less= C * e ^ (epsilon * (absolute-value@(x)) ^ 2), formulae@(absolute-value@(D _ x * u * open-interval@(t, x)) less= C * e ^ (epsilon * (absolute-value@(x)) ^ 2), formulae@(t > 0, x element-of R ^ n)))

para.p:
If
f
and
g
are
C 2
functions on some open set in
× R
R n
, such as
×
( 0 , ∞ )
R n
, then

Math.text: g * ((partial-differential _ t)@(f) - Delta * f) + f * ((partial-differential _ t)@(g) + Delta * g) = ((partial-differential _ t)@(f * g) - g * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((partial-differential _ j) ^ 2)@(f))) + f * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((partial-differential _ j) ^ 2)@(g)) = (partial-differential _ t)@(f * g) + ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((partial-differential _ j)@(f * (partial-differential _ j)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ j)@(f))) = div _ (list@(t, x)) * F
g * ((partial-differential _ t)@(f) - Delta * f) + f * ((partial-differential _ t)@(g) + Delta * g)
((partial-differential _ t)@(f * g) - g * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((partial-differential _ j) ^ 2)@(f))) + f * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(((partial-differential _ j) ^ 2)@(g))
(partial-differential _ t)@(f * g) + ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((partial-differential _ j)@(f * (partial-differential _ j)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ j)@(f)))
div _ (list@(t, x)) * F

para.p: where

Math.text: F = vector@(f * g, f * (partial-differential _ 1)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ 1)@(f), ldots, f * (partial-differential _ n)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ n)@(f))

para.p:
Take
>
t 0
0
,
∈
x 0
R n
, and let
=
⁢ f
( t , x )
⁢ u
( t , x )
and
=
⁢ g
( t , x )
⁢ k
(
-
t 0
t
,
- x
x 0
)
for
> t 0
,
∈ x
R n
. Let
0 < a < b <
t 0
and
> r 0
, and define

Math.text: Omega = conditional-set@(open-interval@(t, x), formulae@(absolute-value@(x) less r, a less t less b))

para.p:
In
Ω
we check that
=
⁢
(
-
∂ t
Δ
)
f
0
and
=
⁢
(
+
∂ t
Δ
)
g
0
, so by the divergence theorem,

Math.text: (integral _ (partial-differential@(Omega)))@(F cdot nu) = (integral _ Omega)@(div _ (list@(t, x)) * F) = (integral _ Omega)@(g * ((partial-differential _ t)@(f) - Delta * f)) + f * ((partial-differential _ t)@(g) + Delta * g) = (integral _ Omega)@(g cdot 0) + f cdot 0 = 0

para.p: On the other hand, as

Math.text: partial-differential@(Omega) = conditional-set@(open-interval@(b, x), absolute-value@(x) less= r) union conditional-set@(open-interval@(a, x), absolute-value@(x) less= r) union conditional-set@(open-interval@(t, x), formulae@(a less t less b, absolute-value@(x) = r))

para.p: we have

Math.text: (integral _ (partial-differential@(Omega)))@(F cdot nu) = (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(((F * open-interval@(b, x)) cdot vector@(1, 0, ldots, 0)) * differential-d@(x)) + (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(((F * open-interval@(a, x)) cdot vector@(- 1, 0, ldots, 0)) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(((F * open-interval@(t, x)) cdot (x / r)) * differential-d@(sigma) * x * t ^ (n - 1) * differential-d@(t))) = ((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(f * open-interval@(b, x) * g * open-interval@(b, x) * differential-d@(x)) - (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(f * open-interval@(a, x) * g * open-interval@(a, x) * differential-d@(x))) + ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((f * (partial-differential _ j)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ j)@(f)) * open-interval@(t, x) * (x _ j / r) * d * sigma * x * t ^ (n - 1) * d * t))) = ((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(u * open-interval@(b, x) * k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - b, x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x)) - (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(u * open-interval@(a, x) * k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - a, x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x))) + ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((u * open-interval@(t, x) * (partial-differential _ j)@(k) * open-interval@(t _ 0 - t, x - x _ 0) - k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - t, x - x _ 0) * (partial-differential _ j)@(u) * open-interval@(t, x)) * (x _ j / r) * d * sigma * x * t ^ (n - 1) * d * t)))
(integral _ (partial-differential@(Omega)))@(F cdot nu)

(integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(((F * open-interval@(b, x)) cdot vector@(1, 0, ldots, 0)) * differential-d@(x)) + (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(((F * open-interval@(a, x)) cdot vector@(- 1, 0, ldots, 0)) * differential-d@(x))
+ ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(((F * open-interval@(t, x)) cdot (x / r)) * differential-d@(sigma) * x * t ^ (n - 1) * differential-d@(t)))

(integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(f * open-interval@(b, x) * g * open-interval@(b, x) * differential-d@(x)) - (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(f * open-interval@(a, x) * g * open-interval@(a, x) * differential-d@(x))

+ ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((f * (partial-differential _ j)@(g) - g * (partial-differential _ j)@(f)) * open-interval@(t, x) * (x _ j / r) * d * sigma * x * t ^ (n - 1) * d * t)))

(integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(u * open-interval@(b, x) * k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - b, x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x)) - (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) less= r))@(u * open-interval@(a, x) * k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - a, x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
where
σ
is surface measure on
{ | x | = r }
= r
S
- n 1
. As
→ r ∞
, the first two terms tend to

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(u * open-interval@(b, x) * k _ (t _ 0 - b) * (x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(u * open-interval@(b, x) * k _ (t _ 0 - b) * (x _ 0 - x) * differential-d@(x)) = u * open-interval@(b, cdot) * k _ (t _ 0 - b) * x _ 0

para.p: and

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ n))@(u * open-interval@(a, x) * k _ (t _ 0 - a) * (x - x _ 0) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(u * open-interval@(a, x) * k _ (t _ 0 - a) * (x _ 0 - x) * differential-d@(x)) = u * open-interval@(a, cdot) * k _ (t _ 0 - a) * x _ 0

respectively. Let

Math.text: n * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@((C * e ^ (epsilon * r ^ 2) * (absolute-value@(x - x _ 0) / (2 * t)) * k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - t, x - x _ 0) + k * open-interval@(t _ 0 - t, x - x _ 0) * C * e ^ (epsilon * r ^ 2)) * differential-d@(sigma) * x * t ^ (n - 1) * differential-d@(t)))

Math.text: n * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) = r))@(C * e ^ (epsilon * r ^ 2) * ((absolute-value@(x _ 0) + r) / (2 * a) + 1) * (4 * pi * (t _ 0 - b)) ^ (- n / 2) * exponential@(- r ^ 2 / (4 * (t _ 0 - a))) * differential-d@(sigma) * x * t ^ (n - 1) * differential-d@(t)))

and writing

para.p:
which tends to

as

. Therefore,

One checks that as

t 0

This is true for any

We extend
k
to
× R
R n
as

Math.text: k * open-interval@(t, x) = cases@((4 * pi * t) ^ (- n / 2) * exponential@(- (absolute-value@(x)) ^ 2 / (4 * t)), formulae@(t > 0, x element-of R ^ n), 0, formulae@(t less= 0, x element-of R ^ n))

para.p:
This function is locally integrable in
× R
R n
, so it makes sense to define
∈
Λ k
⁢
D ′
(
× R
R n
)
by

Math.text: formulae@(Lambda _ k * phi = (integral _ R)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t))), phi element-of D * R * R ^ n)

para.p:
Suppose that
P
is a polynomial in
n
variables:

Math.text: P * xi = sum@(c _ alpha * xi ^ alpha) = sum@(c _ alpha * (xi _ 1) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (xi _ n) ^ (alpha _ n))

para.p:
We say that
∈ E
⁢
D ′
(
R n
)
is a fundamental solution of the differential operator

Math.text: P * D = sum@(c _ alpha * D _ alpha) = sum@(c _ alpha * i ^ (- absolute-value@(alpha)) * D ^ alpha)

if
=
⁢ P
( D )
E

( D )
. We now prove that the heat kernel extended to
× R
R n
in the above way is a fundamental solution of the heat operator. 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 Gerald B. Folland, Introduction to Partial Differential Equations, second ed., p. 146, Theorem 4.6.

Math.text: absolute-value@((integral _ R)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@((k * open-interval@(t, x) - K _ epsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * phi * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t)))) = absolute-value@(((integral _ 0) ^ epsilon)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(t, x) * phi * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t)))) less= (norm@(phi)) _ infinity * ((integral _ 0) ^ epsilon)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t))) = (norm@(phi)) _ infinity * ((integral _ 0) ^ epsilon)@(differential-d@(t)) = (norm@(phi)) _ infinity * epsilon
absolute-value@((integral _ R)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@((k * open-interval@(t, x) - K _ epsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * phi * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t))))

(norm@(phi)) _ infinity * ((integral _ 0) ^ epsilon)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t)))

This shows that
→

, with the weak-* topology. It is a fact that for any multi-index,

E

Let
∈ ϕ

(

. Doing integration by parts,

Math.text: (D _ t - Delta) * Lambda _ K _ epsilon * phi = Lambda _ K _ epsilon * (D _ t - Delta) * phi = (integral _ R)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(K _ epsilon * open-interval@(t, x) * (D _ t * phi * open-interval@(t, x) - Delta * phi * open-interval@(t, x)) * differential-d@(x) * t * x)) = ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(t, x) * D _ t * phi * open-interval@(t, x))) - k * open-interval@(t, x) * Delta * phi * open-interval@(t, x) * d * x * t * x = (integral _ (R ^ n))@((k * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * phi * open-interval@(epsilon, x) - ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * D _ t * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(t))) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * Delta * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t))) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * phi * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * differential-d@(x)) - ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * (D _ t - Delta) * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(t) * differential-d@(x))) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * phi * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * differential-d@(x))
(D _ t - Delta) * Lambda _ K _ epsilon * phi
Lambda _ K _ epsilon * (D _ t - Delta) * phi
(integral _ R)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(K _ epsilon * open-interval@(t, x) * (D _ t * phi * open-interval@(t, x) - Delta * phi * open-interval@(t, x)) * differential-d@(x) * t * x))

((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(t, x) * D _ t * phi * open-interval@(t, x))) - k * open-interval@(t, x) * Delta * phi * open-interval@(t, x) * d * x * t * x

+ ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * Delta * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t)))

- ((integral _ epsilon) ^ infinity)@((integral _ (R ^ n))@(phi * open-interval@(t, x) * (D _ t - Delta) * k * open-interval@(t, x) * differential-d@(t) * differential-d@(x)))
(integral _ (R ^ n))@(k * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * phi * open-interval@(epsilon, x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
So, using
=

⁢

Math.text: (D _ t - Delta) * Lambda _ K _ epsilon * phi = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(k _ epsilon * (- x) * phi _ epsilon * x * differential-d@(x)) = k _ epsilon * phi _ epsilon * 0 = k _ epsilon * phi _ 0 * 0 + k _ epsilon * (phi _ epsilon - phi _ 0) * 0
(D _ t - Delta) * Lambda _ K _ epsilon * phi
(integral _ (R ^ n))@(k _ epsilon * (- x) * phi _ epsilon * x * differential-d@(x))
k _ epsilon * phi _ epsilon * 0
k _ epsilon * phi _ 0 * 0 + k _ epsilon * (phi _ epsilon - phi _ 0) * 0

para.p: Using the definition of convolution, the second term is bounded by

Math.text: (supremum _ (x element-of R ^ n))@(absolute-value@(phi _ epsilon * x - phi _ 0 * x) * (norm@(k _ epsilon)) _ 1) = (supremum _ (x element-of R ^ n))@(absolute-value@(phi _ epsilon * x - phi _ 0 * x))

This section is my working through of material in Folland. 5 footnote 5 5 footnote 5 Gerald B. Folland, Introduction to Partial Differential Equations, second ed., pp. 149–152, §4B. For
∈ f
S n
and for any nonnegative integer
k

Math.text: formulae@(F * (- Delta) ^ k * f * xi = (integral _ (R ^ n))@((- Delta) ^ k * f * x * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(x)) = (4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) ^ k * F * f * xi, xi element-of R ^ n)

para.p:

para.p:

para.p: which one calculates is equal to

Math.text: (Gamma * (n / 2 - beta)) / (Gamma * beta * 4 ^ beta * pi ^ (n / 2) * (absolute-value@(x)) ^ (n - 2 * beta))

para.p:
What we have written so far does not prove that this is the convolution kernel of
(
- Δ

because it used (), but it is straightforward to calculate that indeed the convolution kernel of
(

is (). This calculation is explained in an exercise in Folland. 8 footnote 8 8 footnote 8 Gerald B. Folland, Introduction to Partial Differential Equations, second ed., p. 154, Exercise 1.

Taking
= α
⁢ 2 β
and defining

Math.text: formulae@(formulae@(R _ alpha * x = (Gamma * ((n - alpha) / 2)) / (Gamma * (alpha / 2) * 2 ^ alpha * pi ^ (n / 2) * (absolute-value@(x)) ^ (n - alpha)), 0 less Re * alpha less n), x element-of R ^ n)

para.p:
we call
R α

α

(

Math.text: formulae@((- Delta) ^ (- alpha / 2) * f = R _ alpha * f, f element-of S _ n)

> n 2
and

< n

Math.text: R _ 2 * x = 1 / ((n - 2) * omega _ n * (absolute-value@(x)) ^ (n - 2))

para.p:
We write
= α
⁢ 2 β
and define, for
>
⁢ Re α
0

Math.text: formulae@(B _ alpha * x = (1 / (Gamma * (alpha / 2) * (4 * pi) ^ (n / 2))) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(tau ^ ((alpha - n) / 2 - 1) * e ^ (- tau - (absolute-value@(x)) ^ 2 / (4 * tau)) * differential-d@(tau)), x not-equals 0)

para.p:
We call
B α
the Bessel potential of order
α
. It is straightforward to show, and shown in Folland, that
<

∥
1
∞

∈
B α

)

B α

Math.text: formulae@((widehat@(B)) _ alpha * xi = (1 + 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) ^ (- alpha / 2), xi element-of R ^ n)

para.p: and then

Math.text: formulae@(psi * (- Delta) = (1 - Delta) ^ (- alpha / 2) * f = B _ alpha * f, f element-of S _ n)

para.p:
If
μ

R n
and
: f

C

∈ x
R n

∫
R n
⁢ f

)

( y )

* μ f

Math.text: mu * f * x = mu * tau _ x * check@(f) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(tau _ x * check@(f) * y * differential-d@(mu) * y) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(check@(f) * (y - x) * differential-d@(mu) * y) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(f * (x - y) * differential-d@(mu) * y)

para.p:
Let
ν t
be the measure on
R n
with density
k t
. We call
ν t
Gaussian measure. It satisfies

Math.text: formulae@(nu _ t * f * x = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(f * (x - y) * differential-d@(nu _ t) * y) = (integral _ (R ^ n))@(f * (x - y) * k _ t * y * differential-d@(y)) = f * k _ t * x, x element-of R ^ n)
